column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0001] This application is a continuation-in-part of application Ser.
#Text=This application further claims priority to Provisional Application No. 60/670,467, filed Apr. 11, 2005.
#Text=Both of these applications are incorporated herein by reference in their entirety.
#Text=[0002] Provided are devices and methods for performing hybridization and binding assays using thermophoresis.
#Text=[0003] An efficient method of sequencing DNA is by means of hybridization to known nucleotide sequences arranged in microarrays.
#Text=See e.g., PCT WO 89/10977.
#Text=In this method a solution of single strands of unknown DNA is mixed with an array of oligonucleotides which are fixed to a substrate.
#Text=The oligonucleotides vary in sequence, and each unique sequence occupies a small region on the substrate whose position is known.
#Text=If the sequence of a given oligonucleotide region is complementary to the unknown DNA target molecule, then the DNA strands will hydrogen bond or hybridize to the oligonucleotides at that site.
#Text=Since the oligonucleotide sequence is known, that part of the mixture which bound to the oligonucleotide is then determined as well.
#Text=If the DNA is fragmented into lengths comparable to the lengths of the oligonucleotides, then the entire DNA sample can, in principle, be sequenced.
#Text=This method may also be used to study gene expression, as described in D.
#Text=Murphy, Adv.
#Text=Physiol.
#Text=RNA expressed by genes in a sample is collected, converted to complementary DNA (cDNA) and applied as described above to the microarray.
#Text=[0004] The sites in the microarray at which the DNA binds can be identified by attaching tags to the fragments before hybridization.
#Text=These tags can be radioactive, fluorescent, or luminescent, for example.
#Text=By scanning the hybridized microarray for radioactivity or fluorescence, the hybridized sites can be identified.
#Text=[0005] The power of this technology lies in the discriminatory ability of the hybridization process.

#Text=For DNA fragments on the order of 20 nucleotides in length or less, a single mismatch in nucleotide base pairs can significantly affect the hybridization process, and more than one adjacent base pair mismatch can effectively prevent hybridization.
#Text=The degree of discrimination is controlled by the conditions in the solution: the types and concentrations of buffers and the temperature.
#Text=The degree to which nucleic acids hybridize is referred to as "stringency".
#Text=In a state of high stringency conditions, hybridization rate is reduced and the probability of base pair mismatches is reduced even more.
#Text=In a condition of low stringency, hybridization becomes more likely and the probability of base pair mismatches increases.

#Text=In general, high stringency conditions and high discrimination against base pair mismatches are characterized by higher temperature, lower ionic strength, low reactant concentration, and short reaction times.
#Text=In addition, many washings of the microarray with hybridization buffers are done to remove sample DNA strands which have not hybridized to probe oligonucleotides.
